name: HIP 41378
scenarioDescription:
The HIP 41378 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HIP 41378 is a star with 1.17 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.34 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system.

HIP 41378 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HIP 41378 system


HIP 41378 b

HIP 41378 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 41378 b is 8.745 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 41378 b is 2.9 that of Earth. At 8.745 Earth masses, HIP 41378 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


HIP 41378 c

HIP 41378 c was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 41378 c is 7.0914 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 41378 c is 2.56 that of Earth. At 7.0914 Earth masses, HIP 41378 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


HIP 41378 d

HIP 41378 d was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 41378 d is 14.8506 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 41378 d is 3.96 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HIP 41378 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HIP 41378 e

HIP 41378 e was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 41378 e is 26.0442 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 41378 e is 5.51 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HIP 41378 e is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HIP 41378 f

HIP 41378 f was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 41378 f is 74.09400000000001 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 41378 f is 10.2 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HIP 41378 f is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HIP 41378, which contains undefined planets and was discovered by undefined.
